<color=#1dd215>To Haniyyah and Souka:
My dear friends, it's been far too long. How have you been? And how are your Fungi friends doing?
I hear you'll soon be settling down in Bayda Harbor. That's certainly something worth celebrating!
When the time comes, please let me know. I'll come over together with Miss Najah.
In addition to the gifts prepared for the two of you, I've also made some little outfits for the Twirly-Whirly.
Recently, there has been one piece of bad news, and one piece of good news.
The bad news is about the Wisdom Orb...
Some problems can't be solved with money alone. For all this time, Miss Najah has given it everything she has, but she's still unable to alter the underlying mechanism of the Wisdom Orb.
According to her, the elemental irregularities caused by this type of devices stem entirely from their operational principles. As long as their core functions are retained, the risks will remain unavoidable.
As a result, everyone is now inclined to abandon this particular technology.
That said, based on your letters and on seeing how happily your Fungus companions have grown over the years, I truly believe that even without relying on any devices, you'll be able to carve out a new path. One that allows you to reliably identify friendly Fungus companions and establish a complete set of methods for coexisting with them.
The good news is that the materials you sent, along with the draft of On Fungi Communities, have provided unparalleled real-world case studies for the field of Fungus Studies.
By now, even students like myself at the Rtawahist have heard that Fungus Studies has received funding on a scale far beyond anything in the past.
If one day it grows into a major discipline with many scholars, who knows, perhaps the Akademiya will even invite Haniyyah to serve as a consultant.
